DataElement.preferredName: Gene Mutation Second Gene HGNC Symbol Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The HGNC gene symbol for the second coding region in a mutation that spans two gene locations (Example: fusion, translocation, inversion).

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The result of any gain, loss or alteration of the sequences comprising a gene, including all sequences transcribed into RNA.:The gene symbol that represents the gene that comprises the 3' portion of the coding sequence for a fusion gene.

Concepts.definition: The result of any gain, loss or alteration of the sequences comprising a gene, including all sequences transcribed into RNA.

Property.preferredDefinition: The gene symbol that represents the gene that comprises the 3' portion of the coding sequence for a fusion gene.

Concepts.definition: The gene symbol that represents the gene that comprises the 3' portion of the coding sequence for a fusion gene.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).

DataElementConcept.administrativeNotes: 11/11/23 Released per PCDC-U of Chicago/Mei Li. BF;4/24/2023: added Origin to DEC.wz

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The worldwide authority that assigns standardized nomenclature to human genes. The HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee is responsible for approving unique symbols and names for human loci, including protein coding genes, ncRNA genes, and pseudogenes, to allow unambiguous scientific communication. It is jointly funded by the US National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI) and Wellcome (UK) and operates under the auspices of the Human Genome Organization (HUGO)._An arbitrary sign (written or printed) that has acquired a conventional significance._The words or language units by which a thing is known.
